author: By David McCabe and Steve Lohr
title: Social Media Restrictions on Biden Officials Are Paused in Appeal
description: A Fifth Circuit panel temporarily lifted a judge’s order that had blocked the administration from contacting platforms about most of their content.
content: A federal appeals court on Friday paused a judge’s order that had blocked much of the Biden administration from talking to social media sites about content.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Maria Varenikova
title: A Ukrainian commander describes the grueling battle against dug-in Russian forces.
description: Troops with the 36th Marine Brigade have been the tip of the spear in Ukraine’s counteroffensive and have advanced about five miles into a bulge into Russian lines in southern Ukraine.
content: Even as he commanded troops in a fierce, weeklong fight to capture one Russian position, Col. Viktor Sikoza received disturbing news: The Russians were using this time to build yet another fortification behind it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chang Che and Olivia Wang
title: What Happens When You Ask a Chinese Chatbot About Taiwan?
description: We spoke in Chinese to Baidu’s Ernie and the American standard-bearer, ChatGPT. This is what we found.
content: Last month, China’s Baidu unveiled a chatbot that it claimed was better than ChatGPT, the one developed by Silicon Valley’s OpenAI. ChatGPT was released last fall and set off a fund-raising and engineering frenzy in a flourishing field called generative artificial intelligence, a term for technology that can create text or images when prompted by a user.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: ‘10 Seconds’: Outrage Follows Acquittal in Italy Abuse Case
description: A court in Rome said it had decided to acquit a janitor accused of improperly touching a student in part because the episode lasted “a handful of seconds” and took place in a public area in front of other students.
content: For days, many Italians have flooded social media with two unusual calls to outrage: “#10secondi” and “#palpatabreve,” or “10 seconds” and “brief grope.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Sherwood
title: 5 Restaurants in Naples Where You Can Forget About Pizza
description: Fried zucchini, classic ziti with Neapolitan ragù, mussel soup and artichoke hearts filled with mountain truffle cream: When it comes to food, there’s more to this coastal Italian city than pizza.
content: The worldwide culinary fame of Italy’s third-largest city boils down to one word: pizza. You can hardly hurl a tomato in the food’s purported birthplace — a scruffy, graffiti-stained port city of monumental Baroque buildings and narrow cobbled passageways — without hitting a gaggle of culinary pilgrims jockeying to enter one of the hundreds (or thousands, by some counts) of pizzerias.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Precious Adesina
title: Blending Dance and Sculpture Creates a Fresh View of Art
description: An exhibition at the Barnes Foundation in Philadelphia is one of several recent projects using the two forms to explore how people interact with art.
content: The Chicago artist Brendan Fernandes doesn’t need his work to fit neatly into one category. “People ask, ‘Is it a prop? Is it a sculpture? Is it an artwork?’ And I’m like, ‘It’s all those things,’” he said recently by phone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miya Lee
title: Love Letter: A Second Skin to Escape Racism
description: Tired of encountering overt racism while dating, a Korean American man finds liberation in latex.
content: “On gay dating apps, East Asians routinely face dehumanization that reduces us to nothing more than featureless clones in the eyes of others,” Preston Gyuwon So writes in this week’s Modern Love essay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: New York’s Public Theater Lays Off 19 Percent of Its Staff
description: The institution, a titan among nonprofit theaters, is suffering from the combined effects of falling revenue and rising costs plaguing the arts world.
content: The Public Theater, one of the nation’s most prestigious and successful nonprofit theaters, laid off 19 percent of its staff on Thursday as a financial crisis sweeps across the field.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Wagner Troops Can Keep Fighting, but Without Prigozhin, Putin Says
description: As Russia’s president reasserts control after a failed mutiny, he wants to sideline the Wagner leader while keeping its fighters — who have started training troops in Belarus — working for him.
content: Three weeks after a brief mutiny in Russia by the Wagner mercenary group, President Vladimir V. Putin said its troops could keep fighting, but without their controversial leader, while the government of Belarus said some Wagner fighters were there, training its forces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: U.S. Virgin Islands Seeks $190 Million From JPMorgan in Epstein Lawsuit
description: The U.S. territory wants JPMorgan to pay damages for failing to spot Jeffrey Epstein’s activities on the island.
content: The government of the U.S. Virgin Islands said in a court filing on Friday that it is seeking at least $190 million in penalties from JPMorgan Chase for the bank’s failure to detect and report the sex trafficking operation run by the disgraced financier Jeffrey Epstein in the U.S. territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Bastille Day Is Usually a Fireworks Bonanza. Not This Year.
description: Many French cities canceled their traditional firework shows over a familiar issue in France, social unrest, and a more daunting one, climate change.
content: Bastille Day in France has long been synonymous with grand fireworks displays over towns and villages, as dancing crowds celebrate their nation’s revolutionary birth.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Newly Published, From Nuclear Close Calls to Hollywood’s Greatest Love Affair
description: A selection of recently published books.
content: ANAÏS NIN: A Sea of Lies, by Léonie Bischoff. Translated by Jenna Allen. (Fantagraphics, $29.99.) The writer’s exploration of her sensual inner life — “few know how many women live inside of me,” she says — is gorgeously rendered by Bischoff in rich, undulating, jewel-toned color pencil illustrations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Daniels
title: In ‘The League,’ Black Baseball’s Field of Dreams
description: Five questions for the director Sam Pollard about his documentary, and the preservation of the history of the Negro leagues.
content: Sam Pollard’s documentary “The League” introduces audiences to the teams, stars and little-known figures who populated the Negro leagues by chronicling how Black professional baseball first sprouted. It covers the period from just before the majors instituted a gentlemen’s agreement banning African Americans from playing with white players, to the Negro leagues becoming one of America’s biggest Black-owned businesses, to its demise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Daniels
title: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
description: From angst-ridden military dads to the threat of doomsday cults, this month’s action picks push their heroes to the edge.
content: Since the even-keeled Jamie (Clayne Crawford), an Army veteran, returned home to New Orleans, times have been difficult: His daughter needs an operation. When his impulsive brother, Mic (Max Martini), approaches him about a bank robbery job, the financial gain becomes too much to ignore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Montgomery
title: An Oasis in the Middle of a Scorching Texas Summer
description: Barton Springs, whose cool, natural waters have created summer memories for generations in Austin, Texas, has become an important refuge during the current heat wave.
content: It was six o’clock on Friday morning, at least 15 minutes before dawn over Texas’ capital city, and scores of vehicles had already crowded into the parking lot at Barton Springs Pool, a few miles — and in some ways, an entire world — from the lighted skyscrapers of downtown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: André Watts, Pioneering Piano Virtuoso, Dies at 77
description: One of the first Black superstars in classical music, he awed audiences with his charisma and his technical powers.
content: André Watts, a pianist whose mighty technique and magnetic charm awed audiences and made him one of the first Black superstars in classical music, died on Wednesday at his home in Bloomington, Ind. He was 77.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: July 14, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, July 14, 2023.
content: An obituary on July 3 about the meteorologist Frank Field misstated where he was born. It was Brooklyn, not Queens. It also misstated when his wife, Joan, died. It was last year, not this year. And it omitted the name of a survivor. In addition to those named, Dr. Field is survived by a brother, Allan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: Wells Fargo Beats Expectations but Sets Aside Money for Loan Losses
description: The U.S. economy “continues to perform better than many had expected,” said Charlie Scharf, the bank’s chief executive, but “there will likely be continued economic slowing.”
content: Higher interest rates and rising loan balances helped Wells Fargo top analysts’ expectations for the second quarter, even as it socked away more money as a buffer against bad loans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eleanor Cummins and Andrew Zaleski
title: If Loneliness Is an Epidemic, How Do We Treat It?
description: It can’t be cured; it can be treated.
content: Stephanie Cacioppo thought she would be single forever. “I was an only child,” says Dr. Cacioppo. “I always thought that was my fate to be alone.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Preston Gyuwon So
title: My Fetish for a Second Skin
description: As a gay Korean American, I yearned for the privilege of being heterosexual or white. So I began wearing latex, a new skin.
content: Growing up Korean American in a pearly white city at the foot of the Rocky Mountains, I often wanted out of my own skin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo
title: After Abandoning a Dating App, He Found His Match on Twitter
description: Moments after deleting his profile on JDate, Peter Rosenberg spotted one of Natalie Amrossi’s tweets and reached out to her. Before long, they were spending every weekend together.
content: In April 2020, during the early days of the pandemic, Peter Elliot Rosenberg, a broadcaster for Hot 97, ESPN New York and the World Wrestling Entertainment, had been hosting his radio show from his apartment on Manhattan’s Upper West Side. During that time, Mr. Rosenberg, recently divorced, began to entertain the idea of dating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: They’re Full of Pop
description: Jonathan Kaufman makes his New York Times Crossword debut.
content: Jump to: Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gregory Schmidt
title: For Many Small-Business Owners, a Necessary Shift to Digital Payments
description: The pandemic accelerated a transition to cashless payments, forcing a reckoning among small-business owners. But there are benefits: An owner said one cashless system saved her $3,000 a month.
content: “Making It Work” is a series about small-business owners striving to endure hard times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Block
title: A New Life and a New Name, Both Inspired by Nature
description: Shira Catlin and Morgan Keith became a couple soon after discovering a shared love of the outdoors (which once accidentally triggered a search and rescue call).
content: When Shira Claudelle Catlin and Morgan Joan Keith met, they didn’t waste much time becoming an official couple. Almost one month to the day after connecting on Tinder, they became exclusive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Sternbergh
title: A Beach Town Where Broken People Go to Disappear
description: “The Stolen Coast,” by Dwyer Murphy, is a heist novel involving rough diamonds, crooked lawyers and masters of the double cross.
content: If you, like me, lament the absence in modern-day Hollywood of the whip-smart neo-noir thrillers that flourished in the 1990s — films like “One False Move,” “The Last Seduction,” “After Dark, My Sweet,” “Red Rock West” and “Out of Sight,” to name a few — then I have great news for you. It comes in the form of Dwyer Murphy’s second novel, “The Stolen Coast,” which offers all the abundant pleasures of those films, and more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Maggie Haberman
title: Pence Raises Just $1.2 Million, Aides Say, in Worrying Sign for 2024 Bid
description: The notably low figure raised new doubts about Republican voters’ enthusiasm for the former vice president, as well as questions about whether he will qualify for the first G.O.P. debate.
content: Former Vice President Mike Pence has raised a paltry $1.2 million for his presidential campaign, according to two campaign aides, a sum that raises dire questions about Republicans’ appetite for Mr. Pence in 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: It’s Been a Good Stretch for the Markets, but Not as Good as It Looks
description: While stocks, bonds and money market funds have generated positive returns for the year, a quirk in the calendar is creating deceptively strong performances.
content: It has been a fine half year for stocks, money market funds and, to a lesser extent, bonds — so good, in comparison with last year, that you may feel like celebrating when you look at your quarterly portfolio statement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Penelope Green and Balarama Heller
title: The Strangest Trees Grow in East Hampton
description: At the Folly Tree Arboretum, a natural museum curated by an artist with a historian’s eye, every oak, magnolia and sycamore has its own peculiar tale.
content: The clone of the tree that grew from a seed that went to the moon doesn’t look like much. It’s still a callow sapling, a flurry of bright green leaves on a spindly six-foot trunk. But in 20 years or so, this American sycamore will be a formidable presence at the Folly Tree Arboretum, an unusual collection of some 250 trees planted by Tucker Marder, a 33-year-old artist, on five acres of his family’s land in East Hampton, N.Y.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff, Rikki Novetsky, Nina Feldman, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Eric Krupke, Paige Cowett, Lexie Diao, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Alyssa Moxley
title: How Clarence Thomas Came to Reject Affirmative Action
description: The Supreme Court justice has long been among the most ardent critics of the policy.
content: Supreme Court Justice Clarence Thomas, the second Black justice to sit on the court after Thurgood Marshall, has spent years opposing affirmative action. When the high court struck down the policy last month, Justice Thomas was one of the most influential figures behind the ruling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Northwestern Fires Baseball Coach Amid Turmoil Over Culture in Athletics
description: Jim Foster had been the team’s head coach for a season. His firing came days after the university fired Pat Fitzgerald, its longtime football coach.
content: Northwestern University on Thursday fired Jim Foster, its head baseball coach, just three days after firing its longtime football coach amid a hazing scandal, deepening concerns over a toxic culture in the university’s athletics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles and Lindsay Zoladz
title: Billie Eilish’s Forlorn ‘Barbie’ Ballad, and 10 More New Songs
description: Hear tracks by Troye Sivan, Jamila Woods, C. Tangana and others.
content: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage, and The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: adroit
description: This word has appeared in 22 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word adroit has appeared in 22 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 12 in “The Premier League Crucible Produces Something New: Ideas” by Rory Smith:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi and Leily Nikounazar
title: Alcohol Poisonings Rise in Iran, Where Bootleggers Defy a Ban
description: Iran’s prohibition of the drinking and selling of alcohol has led to a flourishing underground market. But even officials have acknowledged a wave of hospitalizations and deaths in recent months.
content: When a renowned Iranian artist hosted friends at his apartment in Tehran last month, he served, as he did often, a bottle of homemade aragh, a traditional Iranian vodka distilled from raisins, that he had secured from a trusted dealer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: Do You Qualify for Biden’s $39 Billion Student Debt Cancellation?
description: The Education Department announced that more than 800,000 borrowers would see their debt eliminated thanks to fixes made to its income-driven repayment programs.
content: Tens of thousands of borrowers with federal student loans are probably wondering: Is my debt load about to get a little lighter?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Flitter
title: Insurer’s Retreat in Florida Signals Crisis With No Easy Fix
description: Farmers is ending some policies in the Sunshine State as insurers struggle with the rising costs of covering climate change-related damage. No one can agree on whom to blame.
content: Insurers are trapped in a riddle: In a world where the risk of costly disasters is rising but high premiums are squeezing policyholders and angering state regulators, how can they continue to make money?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Summer Reading Contest, Week 6: What Got Your Attention in The Times This Week?
description: To participate, submit your response here by July 21 at 9 a.m. Eastern. This week’s winners will be announced on Aug. 1.
content: Welcome to Week Six of our 14th Annual Summer Reading Contest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Creswell
title: Despite Aspartame Warning, Beverage Companies Likely to Stick With It
description: A health agency warned the artificial sweetener may be a carcinogen, but others say that risk is overblown and consumers flock to the taste.
content: About eight years ago, in response to customer concerns about possible health risks associated with the artificial sweetener aspartame, PepsiCo decided to remove the ingredient from its popular diet soda.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: House Narrowly Passes Defense Bill, Setting Up Showdown Over Social Issues
description: Republicans loaded the measure with a raft of social policy provisions — including limits on abortions, gender transition procedures and diversity training — that have little chance of surviving in the Senate.
content: Republicans on Friday rammed through the House a deeply partisan defense bill that would limit abortion access, transgender care and diversity training for military personnel, setting up a showdown with the Senate. The coming fight could imperil the crucial annual measure to provide a pay raise for troops, set defense policy to counter U.S. adversaries and sustain Pentagon programs at a time of rising threats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos, Michael Gold and Grace Ashford
title: George Santos Used New Campaign Cash to Pay Himself Back
description: Mr. Santos brought in $179,000 in the most recent quarter and spent much of it repaying loans he made to his campaign, new filings show.
content: Representative George Santos, the New York Republican facing federal criminal charges, raised about $179,000 for his re-election campaign from April through June — a modest sum that he used in large part to pay back money he had lent to his past congressional bids.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Women in Congress Put Equal Rights Amendment Back on the Agenda
description: Quotation of the Day for Friday, July 14, 2023.
content: “We can’t let paperwork keep us out of the U.S. Constitution.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Heat Wave Hits Europe, and It’s Only Going to Get Hotter
description: More scorching weather is expected in the southern part of the continent and the Balkans in the coming days. Here’s what to know.
content: A heat wave engulfing southern Europe is expected to send temperatures close to record highs in some areas, prompting officials in Italy, Greece, Spain and elsewhere to impose measures to protect residents and tourists from the scorching conditions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: A Victorian Dinosaur Park Finds Its Way in the 21st Century
description: Statues of extinct animals peek out from the trees, delighting onlookers in this London park. But don’t expect them to be scientifically accurate.
content: Imagine: It’s 1854. The concept of evolution won’t be introduced for another five years or so. The word dinosaur is only about a decade old. There are no David Attenborough documentaries teaching you about extinct animals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: A Century Ago, Golf Fans Watched a ‘Do-or-Die’ Moment
description: Bobby Jones won the first of his four U.S. Opens at a course near what is now Kennedy Airport. The New York Times was there.
content: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we’ll look at a moment in the history of golf that will be recreated where it happened 100 years ago tomorrow. We’ll also get details on why there will probably be more squabbling over the maps for New York’s congressional districts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: What We Know About the Gilgo Beach Victims
description: Rex Heuermann was accused of killing three women and is the prime suspect in the death of a fourth. All were found in the same spot, wrapped in burlap.
content: The three women that Rex Heuermann is accused of killing — Melissa Barthelemy, Megan Waterman and Amber Lynn Costello — were discovered wrapped in burlap near Gilgo Beach on Long Island’s South Shore in December 2010.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadiba Hasan
title: A Breakup That Was the Best Thing to Happen to Them
description: It was a long road to self-acceptance and happily ever after for Joseph Jones and Isaac Archuleta, who struggled to accept his sexuality.
content: When Isaac Leon Archuleta and Joseph Daniel Jones reconnected after four years apart, they learned that a breakup can actually be a gift. From 2010 to 2014, they were in an on-and-off relationship, wrestling with issues that could only be reconciled with time and space. Then, they broke up for good.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Today’s Top News: Hollywood Actors Go on Strike, and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: Ex-New York Resident Sentenced to Life in Prison for Helping ISIS
description: Mirsad Kandic, a Kosovo native who had lived in New York before traveling to ISIS territory, was found guilty last year of conspiracy and of providing material support to the group.
content: In 2013, Mirsad Kandic began working with the Islamic State, helping to advance its campaign of global jihad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden and Dmitry Kostyukov
title: A French Music Maker Lost His Voice. A Comedian Helped Get It Back.
description: The rap producer known as Pone, who has A.L.S., speaks through a computer that makes him sound robotic. He asked a comic impersonator to try to recapture his distinctive sound.
content: Guilhem Gallart used to speak with a thick, southern French accent, his voice deep and slightly nasal, topped by a faint lisp.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Needelman
title: Putting the Rich World of Philadelphia’s Public Art Online
description: At the heart of Conrad Benner’s work is a love for a city that he believes is particularly suited to a thriving street arts community.
content: More Than Likes is a series about social media personalities who are trying to do positive things for their communities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: How Taylor Swift’s ‘Speak Now’ Became the ‘Scary’ Version
description: A fan thought she had ordered a new vinyl pressing of the pop star’s album. But what came out of the speakers was entirely different.
content: Rachel Hunter could not wait to play her new vinyl recording of Taylor Swift’s “Speak Now.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: Rennie Harris’s Hip-Hop Dance Mixtape
description: The choreographer and his Puremovement troupe brought their touring show, “Nuttin’ but a Word,” to Prospect Park for BRIC Celebrate Brooklyn!
content: In the middle of the opening set at BRIC Celebrate Brooklyn! on Thursday, the rapper and performance poet Decora dedicated a song to a man he called a mentor: the folk singer Pete Seeger. The song, played by a full band with horns and electric guitar, was a riff on Seeger’s “Where Have All the Flowers Gone?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Ponsor
title: A Federal Judge Asks: Does the Supreme Court Realize How Bad It Smells?
description: The reported behavior of some justices is not a matter of politics or judicial philosophy. It’s about ethics.
content: What has gone wrong with the Supreme Court’s sense of smell?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The Semiconductor Struggle
description: The U.S. and China are engaged in a great-power struggle, and chips are part of the fight.
content: Publicly, the U.S. and China have turned down the heat recently on their relationship. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen and Secretary of State Antony Blinken have both visited Beijing in recent weeks partly to improve communication between the two countries. “President Biden and I do not see the relationship between the U.S. and China through the frame of great-power conflict,” Yellen said at the end of her trip.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Risk, Regulation and Personal Responsibility in Australia’s Last Frontier
description: Setting off fireworks in the Northern Territory, with a sense of time running out.
content: Standing in line outside a fireworks store in Darwin on the morning of July 1, a man mentioned to me that he had acquired some kind of metal pipe, out of which he was planning to shoot fireworks that night. It was morning, and the store hadn’t opened yet, but he had wanted to arrive early to beat the rush on the one day a year when residents could buy and set off fireworks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaia Pianigiani
title: New Heat Wave Descends on Europe, as It Struggles to Adapt
description: European governments have been slow to put in place broader mitigation strategies for extreme heat, allowing deaths to increase. This year may be no different.
content: Tourists sheltered under umbrellas as they lined up at Florence’s majestic cathedral this week, looking for shade. Street vendors peddled fans and straw hats. Locals splashed their faces at water fountains, all seeking a respite from Europe’s latest heat wave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy and Peter Fisher
title: Saying Goodbye to the Dead. (Again.)
description: Jerry Garcia died in 1995. The band bade fans farewell in 2015. This weekend, Dead & Company will close out its Final Tour. Why can’t we stop quitting one of rock’s beloved acts?
content: The first time Albie Cullen said goodbye to the Grateful Dead was on Aug. 9, 1995.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Corina Knoll and Matt Stevens
title: Actors Picket From Coast to Coast as Strike Gets Underway
description: In Los Angeles and New York, actors and screenwriters braved the heat to admonish the major studios and demand a new deal.
content: It was 10 a.m., adoring union members had already more or less mobbed their president, Fran Drescher, and the crowd was growing by the minute.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colbi Edmonds
title: Iowa Governor Signs Six-Week Abortion Ban Into Law
description: Gov. Kim Reynolds had vowed to approve the ban, which was being challenged in court as she signed it.
content: Gov. Kim Reynolds of Iowa, a Republican, signed a strict abortion ban into law on Friday, even as a judge heard arguments to suspend it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hetty Lui McKinnon
title: 4 Easy Dishes That Embrace Everyday Vegetables
description: These vegetarian recipes transform affordable produce and pantry staples into spectacular dishes.
content: It is impossible to separate vegetables from seasonality — especially at the height of summer — but you can be liberated from the anxiety of cooking certain vegetables at specific times of the year. Eat seasonally if you can, but don’t stress if you can’t. There are enough causes of angst in the world; finding vegetables should not be one of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rajan Menon
title: Europe Keeps Acting Like It Can’t Defend Itself Against Russia
description: The Russian military’s lackluster performance in the war in Ukraine has shown that Europe can, and should, defend itself.
content: Since President Vladimir Putin’s invasion of Ukraine, the narrative of American and European officialdom has been that Russia, a predatory state, is bent on dominating its neighbors, constituting a grave military threat to all of Europe. Finland’s and Sweden’s decisions to join NATO bolster this proposition, and the alliance appeared to accept it at face value during its summit this week in Vilnius, Lithuania.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Strawberry Fields of Wimbledon
description: A team of workers has been racing to pick, pack and transport the more than two million strawberries that are expected to be served over the course of the tournament.
content: It was midmorning and the sun was still rising across the English countryside, but Shakhboz Yakhshiboev had been awake since the early hours. Against the backdrop of first light, Yakhshiboev had been making his way through one of the many 50-yard-long polytunnels that were his assignment for these two weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What’s in a Screenshot?
description: Leaked text messages list the “boundaries for romantic partnership.”
content: Last weekend, Sarah Brady, a semiprofessional surfer, posted a number of screenshots of text messages she claims she exchanged with her then-boyfriend, the actor Jonah Hill. In one of the texts, Hill appears to dictate a highly specific list of “boundaries for romantic partnership,” which included not surfing with men, not maintaining friendships with “women who are in unstable places” and not posting pictures of herself in a bathing suit.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Listening to Beyoncé’s ‘Renaissance’ References
description: A tour through key samples, references and influences on the pop star’s 2022 album as her world tour arrives in North America.
content: Last weekend, I traveled to Toronto to catch the first North American date of Beyoncé’s Renaissance World Tour. I returned home feeling like the human incarnation of the starry-eyed emoji (so many sparkles!) and with a new appreciation for “Renaissance,” the loose and sprawling album that Beyoncé released this time last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: No One Can Needle Tom Cruise Like Henry Czerny Can
description: A star of the first “Mission: Impossible” film makes a welcome return 25 years later, bringing a delight in exposition that few actors can match.
content: “Mission: Impossible” is a franchise known for its big-budget, death-defying stunts, but sometimes there’s nothing more suspenseful than a good old-fashioned, face-to-face staredown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina and Matt Stevens
title: Lisa Marie Presley Died From Bowel Obstruction, Officials Say
description: The singer-songwriter and only child of Elvis Presley died in January after she was found unresponsive, the Los Angeles County Medical Examiner’s office said.
content: Lisa Marie Presley, the singer-songwriter and only child of Elvis Presley, died in January as a result of “a small bowel obstruction” caused by scar tissue that developed after bariatric surgery years ago, the Los Angeles County Medical Examiner’s office said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rhoda Feng
title: Review: In ‘The Saviour,’ Past Trauma Is Very Much Present
description: The gravitational pull of the hurts of yesteryear is on vivid display in Deirdre Kinahan’s drama at Irish Repertory Theater.
content: Back stories can be dangerous things. A character besotted with them — especially reductive trauma-filled ones — colludes in her own miniaturization.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: U.S. Cluster Munitions Arrive in Ukraine, but Impact on Battlefield Remains Unclear
description: U.S. officials and military analysts say the weapons, which are banned by many countries, will ease Ukraine’s artillery ammunition shortage but may not have an immediate impact in the war.
content: U.S. officials and military analysts warn that American-made cluster munitions probably will not immediately help Ukraine in its flagging counteroffensive against Russian defenses as hundreds of thousands of the weapons arrived in the country from U.S. military depots in Europe, according to Pentagon officials.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Small Town ‘Tradio’ and More: The Week in Reporter Reads
description: Articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
content: This weekend, listen to a collection of articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Camille Baker
title: Name That Tune (and the Bird Behind It)
description: Here’s why birding by ear is a “living-in-the-moment experience.”
content: This week, we invite participants to try birding by ear. Practice identifying five species common to your area by their vocalizations. The Sound ID feature of the free Merlin Bird ID app can offer suggestions for which species are calling or singing around you. (People who are deaf or hard-of-hearing may find Merlin’s spectrograms helpful as visual representations of the sounds.)
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Year Is Half Over. Here Are the Books You Might Have Missed.
description: A look back at 2023’s buzziest titles so far.
content: This week on the podcast, Gilbert Cruz is joined by fellow editors from the Book Review to revisit some of the most popular and most acclaimed books of 2023 to date. First up, Tina Jordan and Elisabeth Egan discuss the year’s biggest books, from “Spare” to “Birnam Wood.” Then Joumana Khatib, MJ Franklin and Sadie Stein recommend their personal favorites of the year so far.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang and Hari Kumar
title: India Launches Lunar Mission With a Shot at Winning This Year’s Moon Race
description: Chandrayaan-3, a partial redo of a 2019 mission that ended in a crash, is the first of as many as six missions that could land on the moon in the coming months.
content: India is on its way back to the moon after a rocket lifted off from Sriharikota, a launch site off the country’s East Coast, on Friday afternoon local time.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Tom Hanks
description: The July 14, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Tom Hanks. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Little by Little, Pogacar Gains on Vingegaard at the Tour de France
description: An incremental strategy closes the gap but doesn’t change the yellow jersey, for now.
content: Tadej Pogacar gained a little more time on Jonas Vingegaard in the Tour de France on Friday, preferring to chip away at the reigning champion’s lead rather than making one huge move to grab the yellow jersey — and maybe clinch the Tour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess, Maggie Haberman and Alan Feuer
title: Trump Employee Warned of Charges in Classified Documents Case
description: Prosecutors sent a target letter to a low-level worker at former President Donald J. Trump’s company, suggesting the possibility of indictment and confirming that the investigation is continuing.
content: A low-level employee of the Trump Organization has received a target letter from the special counsel Jack Smith in connection with the investigation into former President Donald J. Trump’s handling of classified documents, suggesting that the employee could face charges and confirming that the broader inquiry continues, according to a person familiar with the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Biden and D.N.C. Announce $72 Million in Fund-Raising, a Substantial Haul
description: The figure far surpasses what Donald Trump raised, though it is well short of what Mr. Trump and his allies collected during the same period in the 2020 election cycle.
content: President Biden’s campaign announced on Friday a combined fund-raising haul of more than $72 million from April through June alongside the Democratic National Committee and a joint fund-raising committee, a figure that far surpasses what former President Donald J. Trump and other leading Republican presidential candidates have announced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Davis Land, Rachel Cohn, Jen Poyant, Alyssa Moxley, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Rowan Niemisto
title: Help! My Boss Won’t Stop Using ChatGPT
description: Kevin and Casey answer your questions.
content: This week, we answer more of your questions, like: What is ChatGPT’s carbon footprint? Why are engineers so sure artificial intelligence will keep getting better? And, why are there so many venture capital bros?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Copeland and Stacy Cowley
title: Three Big Banks Rake In Better-Than-Expected Profits
description: Three of the biggest banks in the United States made a cumulative $22.3 billion in profit last quarter, a hefty jump from the same period last year.
content: Three of the biggest banks in the United States made a cumulative $22.3 billion in profit last quarter, a hefty jump from the same period last year, the lenders reported Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Friday Briefing
description: The expanded Hollywood actors’ and writers’ strike.
content: A Hollywood union that represents 160,000 television and movie actors approved a strike yesterday for the first time in 43 years, bringing the $134 billion American movie and television business to a halt over anger about pay and fears of a tech-dominated future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: My Unexpected Love Affair With ‘Notre Dame de Paris’
description: One reporter is hooked on the French spectacle that mixes acrobatics with a rock opera score.
content: It seemed as if nothing would ever displace “The Phantom of the Opera” as my most-viewed musical.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Climate Protesters and the Museums
description: When protesters attack art in museums. Also: Justice Clarence Thomas and friends; the Ukraine war; A.I. and doctors; cheering for losing teams.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Students, What Questions About Paying for College Can We Answer?
description: We hope to tackle some essential queries — but we need your help.
content: The college admissions process is a fraught one, to put it mildly. But there is one subject that often dominates the discussion: paying for college.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Precious Adesina
title: Contemporary African Royals, in Regalia and Complexity
description: A new photography exhibition at London’s Tate Modern includes images of monarchs from across the continent, steering away from Western imagery.
content: On a wall of London’s Tate Modern, a large photo from 2012 depicts a seated Nigerian king, wearing a green beaded hat and a lavish robe with a portrait of Queen Elizabeth II printed on the front.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: Seeing the World Like a Character From a Disney Classic
description: “Beauty and the Beast,” C.S. Lewis and other classics can offer useful ways of approaching world events, and summer reading.
content: In Disney’s “Beauty and the Beast,” a movie that I’ve loved since childhood, you can tell a lot about people by the way they respond to the enchanted castle. Gaston, the movie’s misogynist boor of a villain, sees a tool to be exploited to sow fear and manipulate others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Rubin
title: Rick Froberg, Singer of Artful Intensity, Is Dead at 55
description: A longtime linchpin of a 1990s underground music scene, he built a devoted and enthusiastic following and was also a prolific visual artist.
content: Rick Froberg, the vocalist and guitarist best known for his work with the influential 1990s post-hardcore band Drive Like Jehu, whose urgent howl was one of rock’s most distinctive voices, died on June 30 in San Diego. He was 55.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Angwin
title: The Gatekeepers of Knowledge Don’t Want Us to See What They Know
description: Why the European Union’s ambitious new rules should be tweaked to allow journalists to access Big Tech data.
content: We are living through an information revolution. The traditional gatekeepers of knowledge — librarians, journalists and government officials — have largely been replaced by technological gatekeepers — search engines, artificial intelligence chatbots and social media feeds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: A Climate Hawk’s Issues With Electric Vehicles
description: Toyota is notoriously skeptical of a rapid transition to all-electric E.V.s. It may have a point.
content: I get why the Biden administration is pushing electric vehicles so hard. To stop the planet from overheating, we’ll eventually need motor vehicles to produce zero greenhouse gas emissions, and only fully electric vehicles can do that. Hybrids, which have combustion engines along with electric motors, will always puff some carbon dioxide (and other bad stuff) out of their tailpipes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Litsky and Alex Traub
title: John Uelses, First to Pole-Vault 16 Feet, Is Dead at 85
description: In an era when track and field athletes could rise to national celebrity, Uelses became a newsreel idol and made the cover of Sports Illustrated.
content: In the 1950s and ’60s, track and field athletes could become models on Wheaties boxes, stars on television and objects of fascination to the news media. There were Bob Richards, an ordained minister and pole-vaulter nicknamed the Vaulting Vicar, and Dick Fosbury, a high jumper whose distinctive leap became renowned as the Fosbury Flop.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Jesse Jackson to Step Down From Rainbow PUSH Coalition
description: A successor to Mr. Jackson, the civil rights leader, will be announced at the group’s convention this weekend. Mr. Jackson, 81, announced in 2017 that he had Parkinson’s disease.
content: The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson Sr., the longtime civil rights leader and former Democratic presidential candidate, plans to step down as president of the Rainbow PUSH Coalition, the organization he founded, the group said in a statement on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: In Iowa, Pence Is Put on the Spot Over Jan. 6
description: An exchange with an Iowa voter who accused the former vice president of putting President Biden in the White House illustrated a larger issue for his 2024 campaign.
content: It was midway through a three-day swing of Iowa for Mike Pence when Luann Bertrand confronted him at a Pizza Ranch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judson Jones
title: Hurricane Calvin Strengthens to a Category 3 and Heads Toward Hawaii
description: The storm is expected to weaken before nearing the state next week.
content: A powerful hurricane that formed in the Pacific Ocean this week strengthened into a Category 3 storm on Friday but it is expected to weaken before coming close to Hawaii, forecasters said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosalie R. Radomsky
title: He Was Spinning Vinyl. She Spun His World Around.
description: Nasir Qadree stopped Chloe Louvouezo on the street and invited her to hear him D.J. A 24-hour date followed the next day.
content: One day in March 2021, Chloe Dulce Louvouezo was on her way to a coffee shop to tackle a creative exercise in “The Artist’s Way” workbook before meeting a friend for lunch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins
title: Belarus says some Wagner fighters are training its forces.
description: Television news footage of a training exercise involving the Russian mercenaries offered a rare, if vague, glimpse of the group after its failed mutiny last month.
content: Belarus’s Ministry of Defense said Friday that soldiers from Russia’s Wagner military company were training its security forces, offering a rare if vague sign of the group’s presence in the country after its failed uprising against Moscow last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: What Tom Hanks Thinks of America
description: The decorated actor discusses his new novel, the magic of typewriters and his read of the American psyche.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica Ackerberg
title: Writers Where They Work
description: Bookshelves, typewriters, pills and booze: Writing spaces can evoke romance, glamour and despair at once.
content: Helen Gurley Brown, the longtime editor of Cosmopolitan magazine and author of books including “Sex and the Single Girl,” at home in New York in 1979. In a 2012 opinion essay for The New York Times, Jamie Brickhouse recalled that Brown was “thoroughly modern, but not contemporary when it came to email. Letters — typed or handwritten — were her preferred way of communicating.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Wonking Out: In Economics, a Game of Teams
description: Were we all equally wrong, or were some more equal than others?
content: HBO may have captivated millions with its series “Game of Thrones,” but economists have lately captivated, well, not millions — maybe a few hundred nerds — with their Games of Teams: noisy and sometimes testy public disputes between opposing factions over economic prospects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim
title: Trump Seeks Court Order to Quash Investigation in Georgia
description: Lawyers for the former president asked the state’s highest court to throw out the work of a special grand jury that investigated 2020 election interference and recommended indictments.
content: In his latest legal maneuver, Donald J. Trump sought a court order on Friday that would throw out the work of an Atlanta special grand jury and disqualify Fani T. Willis, the prosecutor leading an investigation into election interference in Georgia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: They Put on a Show at Camp, and It Changed Their Lives
description: In honor of “Theater Camp,” a new movie about a fictional sleepaway site, we asked Broadway veterans and movie stars for their favorite camp memories.
content: Molly Gordon and Ben Platt met as children at the Adderley School, a theater studio in Los Angeles that runs after-school programs and summer day camps. There are photos and home videos of them starring opposite each other in some very grown-up shows like “Chicago” and “Damn Yankees.” Two decades later — with the help of the actor-writer Noah Galvin, Platt’s fiancé, and the writer-director Nick Lieberman — they have spun those memories of wonky vibrato, stumbling choreography and an ardent sense of belonging into the feature comedy “Theater Camp,” opening Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: In U.K. Trial, Kevin Spacey Denies Abusing Position of Power
description: Facing accusations of sexual assault, the actor defended himself against multiple claims. He also admitted he got “the signals wrong” during one encounter.
content: Kevin Spacey told a British jury on Friday that some of the sexual assault accusations against him were “pure fantasy” and “absolute bollocks.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Strike Prevents Actors From Promoting Films at Premieres or Festivals
description: While on strike, actors are barred from publicizing any studio projects they’ve appeared in. Their absence could affect movie theaters and the festival circuit.
content: It has already been a difficult year for movie theaters, with the North American box office down roughly 20 percent from last year. And that was when actors could promote their films.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Copeland
title: JPMorgan’s Profit Jumps, but Interest Rates Remain a Threat
description: It was another quarter of banner financial results for the largest lender in America.
content: JPMorgan Chase, the largest lender in the United States, made $14.5 billion in profit last quarter, a big jump from the same period last year, it reported on Friday. The bank was helped by growth virtually across the board, including increases in lending and credit-card transactions, as well as relative stability in investment banking. JPMorgan’s stock rose 0.6 percent at the close of trading.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: Syria Authorizes U.N. Use of Border Crossing for Aid, Giving Itself Oversight
description: Under a previous arrangement, the U.N. and other aid agencies had Security Council approval to deliver humanitarian aid to Syria’s northern areas. That agreement, in place since 2014, fell apart two days ago.
content: Syria announced on Thursday that it would give state approval for the United Nations to deliver humanitarian aid into rebel-held northern areas through a contentious border crossing with Turkey, effectively giving President Bashar al-Assad’s government control over all aid deliveries to the northern areas of the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel
title: Putin wants to travel to South Africa next month. The host country would prefer he didn’t.
description: An arrest warrant for the Russian leader from the International Criminal Court has created a diplomatic quandary ahead of an August summit.
content: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia is pushing ahead with plans to attend a summit in South Africa next month, even as the host nation grapples with diplomatic and legal fallout of his expected presence, South Africa’s deputy president said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Estelle Tang
title: At American Apparel, a Sex-Positive Veneer Belied Abuse Underneath
description: Kate Flannery’s “Strip Tees” is a racy, thoughtful memoir of her tenure during the rise and fall of the controversial retail company.
content: After a chance meeting with a recruiter at a dive bar in the winter of 2005, Kate Flannery walked into American Apparel’s Los Angeles headquarters wearing tight surf shorts and her mother’s floppy felt hat. That day — as Flannery writes in her first book, “Strip Tees,” a racy, thoughtful memoir of her tenure during the rise and fall of the controversial company — she watched garment workers produce “quivering piles of kelly-green men’s underwear”; posed for Polaroids in a leg-baring velour romper; and encountered the company’s brash, charismatic founder, Dov Charney, “a flip phone pressed to one ear while another waited in a holster on his belt loop.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Visitors Are Briefly Trapped at Former Home of Agatha Christie
description: In a moment of literary irony, visitors were stranded at Greenway House, where the mystery novelist once lived, when a fallen tree blocked the road.
content: In “And Then There Were None,” the classic novel by Agatha Christie, 10 people are invited to a mansion on a remote island, cut off from the rest of the world. A mystery follows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: The Economic Stakes in the Hollywood Shutdown
description: Strikes by actors and screenwriters have ground movie and TV productions to a halt, with consequences likely to be felt across the entertainment industry.
content: It’s happening: America’s $134 billion movie and TV industry has ground to a halt after the Hollywood actors’ union voted to strike, joining screenwriters and shutting down virtually all productions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: Will There Ever Be Another Popular Mayor of New York City?
description: Eric Adams — like most of his recent predecessors — hovers around a 50 percent approval rating. It’s hard to govern when only half the city is on your side.
content: In the early 1990s, the historian Melvin Holli set out to solve a problem with a book called “America’s Big City Mayors.” Although governing a place like New York or Philadelphia was one of the most important political jobs in the country, we had no scholarly ranking of mayors, no orderly system of evaluating them as we did for presidents, thanks to the work of midcentury academics. Relying on surveys of biographers, social scientists and experts in urban policy and on an elaborate methodology, Mr. Holli concluded that Fiorello La Guardia was the best mayor in the history of the United States. No other New York mayor appeared on the “best” list; three were included among the worst.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: With Offices Vacant, London’s Canary Wharf Seeks Growth Beyond Banking
description: A major bank is leaving its headquarters in London’s purpose-built financial district. But the district’s owner has other plans for the area, which may help it survive the pressures it faces.
content: The gleaming skyscrapers of London’s east skyline, built almost 40 years ago, are home to the headquarters of the world’s biggest banks and tens of thousands of their office workers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: On his stops in Europe, Biden adds to talk of a new Cold War.
description: President Biden and his national security team have contended since he took office that all the easy, tempting comparisons between this era and the Cold War are misleading, a vast oversimplification of a complex geopolitical moment.
content: President Biden and his national security team have contended since he took office that all the easy, tempting comparisons between this era and the Cold War are misleading, a vast oversimplification of a complex geopolitical moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman
title: Uruguay Saw Opportunity in China. It Got Schooled in the Hazards of Trade.
description: Uruguay’s pursuit of a trade deal with China has angered its powerful neighbors while failing to yield economic gains.
content: Word that Uruguay was seeking a trade deal with China prompted exultation at El Álamo ranch, a lush expanse of grass punctuated by cactus and herds of cattle on the eastern plains of Uruguay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Rennison and J. Edward Moreno
title: Investors Look for Reasons the Market Could ‘Grind Higher’
description: Companies are expected to report a fall in profits, but some analysts see brighter times ahead.
content: As companies prepare to open their books to investors over the coming weeks, in the quarterly ritual known as earnings season, market watchers are balancing relatively weak estimates for past profits with brighter forecasts for future performance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: My Salary Is Too High. Is It Wrong to Stay in My Job?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on what makes fair compensation.
content: Less than a year ago, I switched from a job at a nonprofit whose mission I was deeply passionate about to a more senior role at a nonprofit in a different sector. I was very underpaid previously and nearly doubled my salary in this new role. Because this role is outside my field of expertise, however, my job satisfaction is not nearly as high as it was in my previous job.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Butter, Garlic, Spice, Sweetness, Umami and Starch
description: Eric Kim’s instant-classic recipe for gochujang buttered noodles is a launching pad for all sorts of improvisations.
content: Good morning. Make any recipe more than three or four times and you’re going to change it, either for reasons of taste or expediency, occasionally both. Make that recipe six or seven times and it’s altered forever. It’s no longer the recipe you originally found. It’s yours.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salamishah Tillet
title: Two Filmmakers, Two Dramas and the Pain of the Foster-Care System
description: The directors of “Earth Mama” and “A Thousand and One” compare notes on complex portraits of Black motherhood that reject ’90s stereotypes.
content: “Earth Mama” opens with a fake-out: a young Black woman named Gia (Tia Nomore) happily tickling a cooing newborn. But as the camera pulls away, a more ambivalent reality is exposed. The baby belongs to an older couple visiting the mall portrait studio to take their family photo, while Gia, very much pregnant, wistfully gazes after them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Hollywood Actors Join in California’s ‘Hot Labor Summer’
description: Actors voted to join screenwriters on the picket lines today — the first time since 1960 that both unions have been on strike at the same time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Maag
title: For Years, Quiet Gilgo Beach Was a Place of ‘Murders and Mayhem’
description: The arrest of a man charged in three of the killings brought a sense of safety to a community long accustomed to being on edge.
content: For a killer looking to hide evidence of his crimes, it was the perfect spot. The straight, quiet stretch of Ocean Parkway would give him plenty of time to listen and watch for coming cars. Just off the road, a tall bramble of bushes and weeds grew so thick and thorny, even trained cadaver-sniffing dogs could barely penetrate it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Louis Langrée Wraps Up a Quietly Transformative Era of Conducting
description: With a new job, Langrée is reaching the end of undersung runs with the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra and the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra.
content: Rehearsals led by the conductor Louis Langrée tend to follow a trajectory. Early on, he speaks poetically and tells stories; during preparations for a May concert with the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra, where he is the music director, he explained Saint-Saëns with references to the Kyrie of a Mass and the paintings of Hieronymus Bosch. But then his language becomes technical and specific; that day, broad explanations of mood gave way to meticulous balance and bowing as the playing took shape like an increasingly detailed, fine sculpture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Britain’s Conservatives Are Imploding
description: Elections next week will tell us how much trouble the Tories are in.
content: Almost the first thing I saw when I arrived in the London suburb of Uxbridge was two teenage girls in school uniforms getting into a fistfight in the shopping mall outside the underground station. Uxbridge is a middle-class place, stodgy but diversifying, whose voters are squeezed by a cost of living crisis and anxious about rising public disorder. Until last month, it was represented by Boris Johnson, and, as the Labour lawmaker Steve Reed told me, it hasn’t sent a member of the left-leaning Labour Party to Parliament since 1966.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: The House Passes a Defense Bill Limiting Abortion Access
description: Also, actors started picketing. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
content: House Republicans, under pressure from a faction of far-right lawmakers, narrowly passed a deeply partisan defense bill today that would limit abortion access, transgender care and diversity training for military personnel. Speaker Kevin McCarthy celebrated it as an effort to force the Biden administration to “stop using taxpayer money to do their own wokeism.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Ashford
title: A.I. Wrote a Housing Bill. Critics Say It’s Not Intelligent.
description: A Queens assemblyman used an artificial intelligence program to identify gaps in New York law. But the resulting bill’s potential impact is murky at best.
content: These days it seems like the reach of artificial intelligence knows no bounds, from generating images, prose and jokes to automating various work functions. But the technological advances can carry hidden costs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer, William K. Rashbaum, Joseph Goldstein and Corey Kilgannon
title: Suspect Arrested in Serial Killings of Women Near Gilgo Beach
description: Rex Heuermann, a 59-year-old architect who lives in Nassau County, was charged with killing three women and is the “prime suspect” in the death of a fourth woman.
content: The bodies were unearthed near remote Gilgo Beach on Long Island’s South Shore more than a decade ago, terrifying residents and leaving the victims’ families bereft. In all, the remains of nine women, a man and a toddler were discovered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: Andy Cruz, Amateur Legend, to Find Out if Pro Boxing Fits
description: Cruz left Cuba to chase his dream to be a professional boxer (and be paid like one). His first fight, against Juan Carlos Burgos, should help him learn how he compares with other contenders.
content: Andy Cruz and Juan Carlos Burgos squared off and locked eyes on a stage set up in a hotel ballroom in downtown Detroit, and did what boxers usually do when they stand face to face.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: Without Hollywood, What Happens to Los Angeles?
description: With actors and screenwriters on strike, Hollywood is shut down for the foreseeable future. Los Angeles isn’t a pure company town, but the industry is inextricable from the city in many ways.
content: Los Angeles County has 88 cities. Ten million people. Two hundred-plus languages spoken.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley
title: Education Dept. Cancels $39 Billion in Student Debt for 800,000 Borrowers
description: One-time credits will wipe out loans, fixing mistakes made by loan servicers when collecting payments under income-driven repayment programs.
content: More than 800,000 borrowers will have $39 billion in federal student loan debt eliminated under a government effort to remedy years of mistakes by the loan servicers that collect payments on the government’s behalf.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Autoworkers Open Contract Talks in a Fighting Mood
description: The U.A.W., with a more confrontational leader, aims to win back wage and benefit concessions and insulate jobs from the rise of electric vehicles.
content: The three Detroit automakers and the United Auto Workers union have begun negotiating a new labor contract in what could become the most contentious talks between the two sides in perhaps half a century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Fire Kills Dozens of Animals at a Florida Rescue Center
description: Up to half of the 250 animals — mostly rescued exotic pets, including chinchillas, a genet and a Vietnamese potbellied pig — perished, the rescue center said.
content: It was a refuge for abandoned exotic pets that Floridians could no longer care for, as well as for orphaned native wildlife, including chinchillas, skunks, stingrays, lizards and alligators — around 250 of them, all told.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: David Balton and Jane Stewart give us an acrostic full of remembrance.
content: ACROSTIC — Today brings the second Times acrostic from David Balton and Jane Stewart. It draws from the 1995 memoir by Barack Obama called “Dreams From My Father.” Nineteen ninety-five? I had to look it up: It was indeed written and published when Mr. Obama was a law professor at the University of Chicago. The book has sold over seven million copies, and even those of us who didn’t read it probably know some biographical information about the 44th president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lola Fadulu
title: A Timeline of Events in the Gilgo Beach Serial Killings
description: The Suffolk County police found 10 bodies while searching for a 24-year-old aspiring actress who had disappeared in 2010. No arrest was made in connection with the killings until now.
content: An architect who had lived most of his life in Nassau County and worked in Manhattan was arrested on Thursday night in connection with the killings of four women near Gilgo Beach on Long Island’s South Shore. The discovery of their bodies and seven others in 2010 and 2011 terrified residents and the case remained unsolved for more than a decade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Franz Lidz
title: When Did Humans First Occupy the Americas? Ask the Sloth Bones.
description: The discovery of ancient, handcrafted ornaments revives a longstanding debate about the arrival of the earliest Americans.
content: Of all the long-running disputes in archaeology, few roil scholars more than the question of when humans arrived in the Americas. For much of the past century, the reigning theory was that in or around 11,500 years ago big-game hunters from Asia trudged to North America across a land bridge spanning the Bering Strait, hung a right through a corridor between glaciers and, in less than a millennium, reached the tip of South America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ann Carrns
title: Water Bills Are Rising. Here’s What to Do About It.
description: Consumers face higher costs as water systems replace old pipes and equipment. Shorter showers and water-efficient appliances can help manage the expense.
content: Scorching temperatures blanketing much of the country make cool showers enticing. But beware the water bill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jancee Dunn
title: Hunching Over Your Computer Like a Buzzard Is Not Helping Your Back
description: It’s time to get up (and fidget).
content: My fragrance of choice for the past year is eau de menthol pain patch. I’ve had chronic back pain, but the cause is not a mystery: I hunch over my computer for hours at a time. Call it “online spine,” “computer-generated back pain,” or, in my case, “Mac back.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: When You Can’t Believe What You’re Seeing
description: The story, more than the sport, is what matters.
content: Nobody is quite sure where the term “kayfabe” originated. It may be a bastardized form of pig Latin, something to do with the actual word “fake.” It may have its roots in the culture of wandering 19th-century carnivals, the world inhabited by P.T. Barnum and the confidence men and the salesmen who sold actual snake oil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Vulnerable Republicans Take a Political Risk With Abortion Vote
description: In uniting his party behind a defense bill loaded with social policy restrictions, Speaker Kevin McCarthy has raised questions over whether his short-term victory could imperil his majority.
content: Representative Jen Kiggans, a minivan-driving mom and Navy veteran, narrowly won election last year in her suburban Virginia swing district after a fiercely competitive race that focused on her opposition to abortion rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Ryder and Photographs and additional reporting by Karen Dias
title: He Followed in the Family Footsteps. And He Found a Home.
description: Anthony Couverthier tried his hand at different jobs, but being a building superintendent came naturally and with an apartment for his family.
content: Anthony Couverthier’s father was a building superintendent. His brother is a super, too. His longtime partner’s stepfather also works as a super. But Mr. Couverthier spent years trying to be something else: a tour manager for a hip-hop group, a store clerk at Sprint, a Home Depot employee. After graduating high school in 1998, he was a communications major at Stony Brook University in Southampton.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: Little Big Men: ‘The Luckiest Guy in the World’ and ‘Goliath’
description: New documentaries explore the star-crossed careers and delicate spirits of Wilt Chamberlain and Bill Walton, two of basketball’s greatest.
content: Pity the poor 7-footer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: How a Jay-Z Retrospective Took Over the Brooklyn Public Library
description: “The Book of Hov,” an elaborate summer exhibition at the borough’s main branch, was quietly conceived by his team as a surprise tribute that opens Friday.
content: Earlier this week, when passages of Jay-Z lyrics from songs like “Hard Knock Life (Ghetto Anthem)” and “Justify My Thug” appeared on the Art Deco-style, curved limestone facade of the Brooklyn Public Library’s main branch, fans and passers-by could only speculate on the occasion for the building’s sudden makeover. A surprise concert for the rapper’s home borough? A tribute to the 50th anniversary of hip-hop this summer?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Reid J. Epstein
title: Biden Switches Up His Big-Money Operation Ahead of 2024
description: The president and his advisers are elevating a new super PAC, Future Forward, as their leading outside group to rake in cash from his wealthiest benefactors.
content: President Biden and his advisers are elevating a new outside group as the leading super PAC to help re-elect him in 2024, making it the top destination for large sums of cash from supportive billionaires and multimillionaires.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: At 600 Square Feet, the Cabin Was Big Enough: ‘It’s Just Me and My Dog’
description: Building a big new house would have been easier and cheaper. But saving the 19th-century structure resulted in something better.
content: When Stephan Weishaupt began looking for a weekend home outside Toronto, buying a 19th-century log cabin was the furthest thing from his mind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: What Really Happened in the Midterms?
description: A segment of swing voters decided to back Democratic candidates in many critical races.
content: More than eight months later, all the data from the 2022 midterm elections is — finally — final. The two most rigorous reports, from the Pew Research Center and Catalist, are finished.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar
title: University of Tennessee Fined Millions for Cash Payments to Athletes
description: The N.C.A.A. said Tennessee had a culture of wrongful payments to athletes, including cash for hotels, meals and car payments, among other things. The university was fined $8 million but avoided a postseason ban.
content: The N.C.A.A. punished the University of Tennessee football program for recruiting violations and direct cash payments to athletes, imposing an $8 million fine and taking away scholarships for what it described as a culture of brazenly skirting rules in hopes of chasing wins.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Israeli Unions and Military Reservists Renew Resistance to Judicial Overhaul
description: Labor groups helped delay earlier efforts to limit the top court’s power. As the government revives its plan, powerful social movements are again voicing their opposition and threatening strikes.
content: Union chiefs, business leaders and military reservists in Israel have warned the far-right government that proceeding with its plan to limit judicial powers without a social consensus will open the door for another wave of national strikes and business closures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman and Olivia Bensimon
title: Finally, Bill de Blasio Wins New Yorkers’ Praise. For His Breakup.
description: Many New Yorkers weren’t impressed with Bill de Blasio as mayor. But the way he’s handling his separation from his wife, Chirlane McCray? “Inspiring.”
content: As a two-term Democratic mayor of New York City, Bill de Blasio earned mixed reviews, at best. But now that he’s out of office, he’s getting raves for the way he is handling an unexpected development: his separation from his wife and the transformation of their marriage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Tucker Carlson Turns a Christian Presidential Forum Into a Putin Showcase
description: The Iowa evangelical leader Bob Vander Plaats gathered Republican White House hopefuls in Des Moines, then gave Tucker Carlson the microphone.
content: Bob Vander Plaats, the conservative evangelical kingmaker in Iowa politics, now knows what happens when you turn over your Republican presidential showcase to Tucker Carlson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: Cluster munitions reach Ukraine a week after Biden’s announcement.
description: U.S.-provided cluster munitions have arrived in Ukraine, U.S. and Ukrainian officials have said, a week after President Biden announced he had made the “very difficult decision” to provide Kyiv with the widely banned weapon.
content: U.S.-provided cluster munitions have arrived in Ukraine, U.S. and Ukrainian officials have said, a week after President Biden announced he had made the “very difficult decision” to provide Kyiv with the widely banned weapon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Mauricio Lima
title: Ruined, Empty, Mined and Overgrown: Ukraine’s Forgotten Villages
description: Settlements along Ukraine’s eastern steppe were reduced to wreckage as the war passed through them. Now choked with weeds and with few residents, they are at risk of disappearing.
content: Leave the eastern Ukrainian city of Izium and turn west onto rougher roads, where dead trees and twisted power lines give way to a string of shattered villages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sofia Quaglia
title: Some Squirmy Stowaways Got to the Arctic. And They Like It There.
description: The unexpected presence of earthworms in the Far North could cause rapid changes in some of the planet’s most fragile ecosystems.
content: Worms are on the move, and people are nervous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Novak Djokovic Relaxes, and Lands in Another Wimbledon Final
description: The 23-time Grand Slam champion may have mellowed, but he is as determined as ever to win his favorite title again. He will play Carlos Alcaraz on Sunday.
content: Six months ago, having just won the Australian Open one year after being deported from the country, Novak Djokovic collapsed in the arms of his family and his coaches in a moment of strained ecstasy.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Margot Robbie And Ryan Gosling Are Bringing “Barbie” to the Big Screen
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabriel Gianordoli and Robert Ito
title: How Manga Was Translated for America
description: The wildly popular Japanese genre is now published close to its original form in the United States. That wasn’t always the case.
content: The wildly popular Japanese genre is now published close to its original form in the United States. That wasn’t always the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Solis
title: The Big Number: 160,000
description: The union representing television and movie actors is on strike, joining screenwriters on the picket lines and creating Hollywood's first shutdown in 63 years.
content: The union representing television and movie actors is on strike, joining screenwriters on the picket lines and creating Hollywood's first shutdown in 63 years.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Read the document
description: A PDF of the Learning Network’s 2022-23 Student Opinion Writing Prompts
content: A PDF of the Learning Network’s 2022-23 Student Opinion Writing Prompts
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miguel Salazar
title: 6 New Paperbacks to Read This Week
description: Including memoirs by Charles McGrath and Doreen Cunningham, fiction by Jamil Jan Kochai, Alexis Schaitkin and more.
content: Including memoirs by Charles McGrath and Doreen Cunningham, fiction by Jamil Jan Kochai, Alexis Schaitkin and more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chun
title: The Weekender
description: The end of the magic world's 50-year grudge. Also in this edition: a boardjacking sea otter and how to sleep better at every age.
content: The end of the magic world's 50-year grudge. Also in this edition: a boardjacking sea otter and how to sleep better at every age.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Cyr Clisset
title: How to Mix and Match Your Sheets
description: There's no rule that your sheets have to match.
content: There's no rule that your sheets have to match.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helmuth Rosales, William J. Broad, Eleanor Lutz and Bedel Saget
title: The Maverick Design Choices That May Have Doomed Titan
description: Engineers interviewed by The New York Times pointed out several weak points in Titan that were cost-saving departures from proven submersible designs.
content: Engineers interviewed by The New York Times pointed out several weak points in Titan that were cost-saving departures from proven submersible designs.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The New York Times News Quiz, July 14, 2023
description: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
content: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Dowling
title: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
description: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including the latest film in the “Mission Impossible” franchise.
content: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including the latest film in the “Mission Impossible” franchise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage, Jared Soares, Marisa Schwartz Taylor and Sean Catangui
title: How to Preserve Priceless Documents at the National Archives
description: The Declaration of Independence. The Bill of Rights. Documents from the present day. And, of course, classified papers once held by presidents of the United States.
content: The Declaration of Independence. The Bill of Rights. Documents from the present day. And, of course, classified papers once held by presidents of the United States.

title: In Ontario, a Tiny Cabin With Style to Spare
description: Building a big new house would have been easier and cheaper. But saving the rotting 19th-century structure resulted in something better.
content: Building a big new house would have been easier and cheaper. But saving the rotting 19th-century structure resulted in something better.

author: By Chevaz Clarke, Meg Felling and Tom Ciaburri
title: Hollywood Productions Grind to a Halt as Actors Go on Strike
description: SAG-AFTRA members voted to walk out after contract negotiations with the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers stalled.
content: SAG-AFTRA members voted to walk out after contract negotiations with the Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers stalled.
